TextEquiv.Unicode: And first of all I will not curiously
put any difference betweene Charitie
and Love. I will use them both in one
and the same sense. S. Augustine De
dostrina Cbristiana saith: I call Cha
ritie a motion of the minde to delight
in God for his owne sake, and to de
light in himelfe and his neighbour for
Gods sake. And therefore I call love
a gift given to man from Heaven,
whereby with his hart he loveth God
before and above all thinges, and his
neighbour as himselfe. Love therefore
springeth from Heaven, from whence
it is powred into our hearts. But it is
inlarged and augmented partly by
the rememdraunce and consideration
of Gods benefits, partly by often pray
er, and also by the hearing & frequen
ting of the worde of Christ. Which
thinges theselves also are the giftes
of the spirite. For the Apostle Paule
saith, The love of God is powred out
into our heartes by the holie Ghost
which is given us. For verily the love
of God wherewith he loueth us, is the
foundation & cause of our love where
with we love him, and of both these
ioyntly cosisteth the love of our neigh
bour. For the Apostle sayth: we love
him because he first loved us. And a
gaine, Everie one that loveth him
which begot, loveth him also that is
borne of him.
Hereby we gather againe, that this
gifte of love can not be divided or fe
vered although it be double. For hee
that loveth God truely, hateth not his
neighbour: and yet neverthelesse this
love, because of the double respect that
it hath to God & our neighbour, stan
deth of two parts. And because of this
double Charitie, the tables of Gods
lawe are divided into twaine : the first
whereof conteineth foure commande
ments touching the love of God, the

And first of all I will not curiously put any difference betweene Charitie and Love. I will use them both in one and the same sense. S. Augustine De dostrina Cbristiana saith: I call Cha ritie a motion of the minde to delight in God for his owne sake, and to de light in himelfe and his neighbour for Gods sake. And therefore I call love a gift given to man from Heaven, whereby with his hart he loveth God before and above all thinges, and his neighbour as himselfe. Love therefore springeth from Heaven, from whence it is powred into our hearts. But it is inlarged and augmented partly by the rememdraunce and consideration of Gods benefits, partly by often pray er, and also by the hearing & frequen ting of the worde of Christ. Which thinges theselves also are the giftes of the spirite. For the Apostle Paule saith, The love of God is powred out into our heartes by the holie Ghost which is given us. For verily the love of God wherewith he loueth us, is the foundation & cause of our love where with we love him, and of both these ioyntly cosisteth the love of our neigh bour. For the Apostle sayth: we love him because he first loved us. And a gaine, Everie one that loveth him which begot, loveth him also that is borne of him. Hereby we gather againe, that this gifte of love can not be divided or fe vered although it be double. For hee that loveth God truely, hateth not his neighbour: and yet neverthelesse this love, because of the double respect that it hath to God & our neighbour, stan deth of two parts. And because of this double Charitie, the tables of Gods lawe are divided into twaine : the first whereof conteineth foure commande ments touching the love of God, the
seconde comprehendeth sire preceptes
touthing the love of our neighbour.
Of which I will speake in their owne
place. But at this time because the
love of God and of our neighbour are
twaine, I will first speake of the love
of God, and then of the love of our
neighbour. In these two commaun
dementes, saith the Lord, hang the law
and the Prophets,
With that which wee call the love
of God we love God intirely well, we
cleave to God as the onely, chiefe and
eternall goodnes, in him we do delight
our selves and are well pleased, and
frame our selves to his will and plea
sure , having evermore a regarde and
desire of him that we love. With love
we love God most heartily. But wee
doe heartily love the thinges that are
deare unto us, and the thinges that to
us seeme worthie to be desired, and we
love them entirely in deede, not so
much for our comoditie, as for because
we doe desire to ioine, and as it were
for ever to give and dedicate our selves
wholely to the thinge that wee so
dearely love. So verily wee desire
for ever to be ioyned with God, & are
in charitie fast linked unto himas the
Apostle saythr God is charitie, and he
that dwelleth in charitie dwelleth in
God, and God in him. And that is the
way whereby we cleave to God as to
the onely chiefe and eternal goodnesse,
in whome also we are delighted, and
that not a litle. On him we rest think
ing alluredly, that without him there
is no good at all: and againe, that in
him there is to be found all manner of
goodnesse. Wherefore our heartie love
is set on no good thing but God: And
in comparison of him whom we love,
we doe lightly loath and treade under
foote all thinges else that seeme to be

seconde comprehendeth sire preceptes touthing the love of our neighbour. Of which I will speake in their owne place. But at this time because the love of God and of our neighbour are twaine, I will first speake of the love of God, and then of the love of our neighbour. In these two commaun dementes, saith the Lord, hang the law and the Prophets, With that which wee call the love of God we love God intirely well, we cleave to God as the onely, chiefe and eternall goodnes, in him we do delight our selves and are well pleased, and frame our selves to his will and plea sure , having evermore a regarde and desire of him that we love. With love we love God most heartily. But wee doe heartily love the thinges that are deare unto us, and the thinges that to us seeme worthie to be desired, and we love them entirely in deede, not so much for our comoditie, as for because we doe desire to ioine, and as it were for ever to give and dedicate our selves wholely to the thinge that wee so dearely love. So verily wee desire for ever to be ioyned with God, & are in charitie fast linked unto himas the Apostle saythr God is charitie, and he that dwelleth in charitie dwelleth in God, and God in him. And that is the way whereby we cleave to God as to the onely chiefe and eternal goodnesse, in whome also we are delighted, and that not a litle. On him we rest think ing alluredly, that without him there is no good at all: and againe, that in him there is to be found all manner of goodnesse. Wherefore our heartie love is set on no good thing but God: And in comparison of him whom we love, we doe lightly loath and treade under foote all thinges else that seeme to be
